results.title: Wool Fashion Awards 1967
results.brief_description: Models are posed against a variety of Melbourne’s buildings such as Melbourne University, Fitzroy Gardens, National Gallery of Victoria…both interior and exterior backgrounds are used. We see the award winning garments: slack suits, lounging pyjamas, coats and dresses for both day and evening wear.

results.title: Wool Fashion Awards of 1960
results.brief_description: Every year, a fashion contest to promote wool as a fabric is held by the Australian Wool Bureau. In 1960, Melbourne compered the awards and this film shows many of the winning entries in the fifty-five sections. Those modelled include suits, coats, dresses, knitwear and slacks. The supreme award for 1960 is the climax of the parade of gold medal winners, held at the end of four days judging.

results.title: Wool Fashion Award
results.creator_credit: Frank Land and Australian Wool Corporation
results.brief_description: Against a background of beauty spots in Sydney, models display the winning styles in frocks, sportswear and costumes of the first fashion awards presented in Australia in 1956. Credits include: fashion adviser Pat Woodley; accessories by David Jones Ltd; photographed by George Heath; compered by Bob Pollard and edited by Sydney Whiteley.

results.title: Victoria: 100 years of progress
results.brief_description:
This documentary looks in detail at the history and development of Melbourne, using artist’s sketches and filmed footage to depict the history of Melbourne. Some items include the Manchester Unity Building, cars of the era travelling down St Kilda Road, St Kilda Beach, a brief history of the Princes Bridge, the Royal Botanic Gardens, Geelong and industries and transport existing in 1934. Also includes footage of the opening of Parliament.

Includes archival footage of early transport-cars; shipping; rail (Flinders Street Station); Prince’s Bridge; St. Kilda Beach; Anzac Parade; Flemington Race Course. Arrival of the Duke and Duchess of York for the first opening of Federal Parliament 1901. Also featured: scenes of the city: Collins and Swanston Streets; Melbourne Town Hill; The Exhibition Building; Parliament House and large private homes in the suburb of Toorak. Reference is made to agricultural and pastoral industries - wheat; wool production; fruit growing and tanning in Mildura. Three masted sailing vessels plus a farewell for the ocean liner Strathnaver. Finally, a re-enactment of gold mining/panning and heralding the first one hundredth birthday of the settlement of Melbourne
[SOURCE: NFSA Collection catalogue)

results.title: Valley of the Yarra
results.creator_credit: Peter McEwan, Donald Pollock, Matthias Faubel and Victorian Town and Country Planning Board
results.brief_description: Using archival stills and prints, and aerial shots the film traces the Yarra River from its source in the Great Dividing Range to its entry into Port Phillip Bay, emphasising its importance as a natural asset. Also shows geographical features such as the delta from Princes Bridge, Melbourne to Fisherman’s Bend, the port complex and various sporting facilities. Discusses the planning policy for the Yarra Valley prepared by the Town and Country Planning Board, Victoria’s state planning authority. “Modern man causes problems to this priceless asset” (Liberal Minister Dick Hamer).

results.title: The Trout harvest
results.creator_credit: Ted Davis, Victoria. Dept. of Fisheries and Wildlife and Victoria. Dept. of Agriculture
results.brief_description: The Snobs Creek fish hatchery was newly established at this time, and this film shows how the fish are bred from the egg stage to liberation into rivers and lakes. This film was included in the San Francisco Film Festival 1961.

results.title: Trees to tame the wind
results.brief_description: In this film we are introduced to a farmer and his son who, in 1934, were distressed by the damage wrought by drought and wind to their farm. At the suggestion of the Forest Service Officer, the farmer decided to carry out a Forest Service plan for planting trees to act as wind-breaks and shelter-belts on his farm, as part of the Prairie States Forestry Project “The Shelterbelt” which extended from North Dakota to Texas. By 1939, this kind of tree planting was being encouraged all over the prairie farmlands in the United States with participation by the farmers an essential part of the program.
